items.body_markdown:
I am currently trying to reproduce the results of *Learning Precise Timing with LSTM Recurrent Networks* by Gers et.al. (cf. http://www.jmlr.org/papers/volume3/gers02a/gers02a.pdf) using Tensorflow's PeepholeLSTMCells.

Therefore, I create a time-series of regular spikes (every 7th datapoint for fast convergence of the net - hopefully). According to the paper, a single LSTM-cell should be capable of learning to reproduce the sequence without any input (I use 0s for simplicity).

In their paper, they will train the net using longer sequences with updates on every sample until the loss exceeds *0.3*.

However, my net will only pickup the first spike and refuses to learn any timing.

Any hints of where my mistake is?

Thank you very much and best regards!

```
import sys
import os
from grpc.beta import _metadata
os.environ['TF_CPP_MIN_LOG_LEVEL'] = '3' 

import tensorflow as tf

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def ml_model(shape, batch_size):
    inputs1 = tf.keras.layers.Input(shape=shape, batch_size=batch_size)
    lstmcell = tf.keras.experimental.PeepholeLSTMCell(1)
    lstm1 = tf.keras.layers.RNN(lstmcell, 
                               stateful=True, 
                               return_sequences=False)(inputs1)
    
    model = tf.keras.Model(inputs=inputs1, outputs=lstm1)
    model.compile(optimizer="adam", loss="mse")
    return model
        
model = ml_model((None, 1), 1)

x = np.zeros(2000)
y = np.zeros(2000)
for i in range(7,2000,7):
    y[i] = 1
max_t  = 0

for j in range(10000):
    loss = 0
    for i in range(200):
        model.reset_states()
        loss = model.train_on_batch(x[:i+1].reshape(1,-1,1), y[i].reshape(-1))
        if(np.sqrt(loss) > 0.3):
            break
    if i > max_t: 
        max_t = i
    print("Run {} length {}, loss = {}".format(j,i, np.sqrt(loss)))

print("Longest run: {}".format(max_t))
yhat = model.predict(x.reshape(-1,1,1))

plt.plot(y.reshape(-1))
plt.plot(yhat.reshape(-1))
plt.show()
```
items.title: Tensorflow LSTM refuses to learn timing

answers.body_markdown:
To speed up copying and pasting values you shall use [batch operations][1], because many different calls to [`getRange`][2] and [`getValues`][3] is slow and inefficient. To run batch operations you will have to use [`getDataRange`][4] to create an array as big as your data table, and then use `getValues` on it to read them in just one operation. You will end up with a two-dimensional array filled with all your data. Finally, you can iterate this array to [splice][5] the elements that don't match your criteria.

If you want to paste your results over a sheet, you have to create a range as big as your results array and use [`setValues`][6] over it. You can refer to [this answer][7] for a comparison of different copy-and-paste algorithms.

Please, tell me the details of your project if you want further help. Do not hesitate to ask me for more clarifications if you have any doubts.


  [1]: https://developers.google.com/apps-script/guides/support/best-practices#use_batch_operations
  [2]: https://developers.google.com/apps-script/reference/spreadsheet/sheet#getrangerow,-column,-numrows,-numcolumns
  [3]: https://developers.google.com/apps-script/reference/spreadsheet/range#getvalues
  [4]: https://developers.google.com/apps-script/reference/spreadsheet/sheet#getdatarange
  [5]: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Array/splice
  [6]: https://developers.google.com/apps-script/reference/spreadsheet/range#setvaluesvalues
  [7]: https://stackoverflow.com/a/57853014

answers.body_markdown:
Without actual access to the data, it is hard to tell what that bullet actually is.  There are a lot of 'bullet' symbols it seems (sort of like how many different kinds of quotes there are!)  Could be a lot of things.  However I've done a little bit of playing and maybe this will help you:

```
--hm! this works, but we are not starting with a bullet
DECLARE @DATA_1 VARCHAR(50)
SET @DATA_1 = 'â€¢ Renew kitchen'
SELECT RTRIM (REPLACE (@DATA_1,'â€¢', '-')) as TEST_1

--basically the problem you are seeing, the bullet is getting flipped into a set of characters
DECLARE @DATA_2 VARCHAR(50)
SET @DATA_2 = '• Renew kitchen' 
SELECT RTRIM (REPLACE (@DATA_1,'•', '-')) as TEST_2

--ok, let's just double translate it?
DECLARE @DATA_3 VARCHAR(50)
SET @DATA_3 = '• Renew kitchen'

DECLARE @DATA_4 VARCHAR(50)
SET @DATA_4 = RTRIM (REPLACE (@DATA_3,'•', '-')) 

SELECT RTRIM (REPLACE (@DATA_4,'â€¢', '-')) as TEST_3```
```

This yields the following results.

[![enter image description here][1]][1]

Hopefully this will do the trick for you, looks like it produces what you are looking for.  The bullet I'm using is the one copy/pasted from the question.  You could also just nest the replaces, I wrote the above so it better shows the thought process.

answers.body_markdown:
You can `join` both tables using the `EmployeeID` as key. Qlik will automatically join on fields with the exact same name. And that's the reason for renaming the `employeeID` field in `Sales` table - to match the field name from `Employee` table. Also we are loading only 2 fields from the `Employee` table - ID (used as key) and Name (to bring this field in `Sales` table)

    Sales:
    Load
      employeeID as EmployeeID,
      Some_Sales_Field_1,
      Some_Sales_Field_1,
      Some_Sales_Field_1
    From
      Sales.csv
      (txt, utf8, no labels, delimiter is ' ', msq)
    ;
    
    left join (Sales)
    
    Load
      EmployeeID,
      EmployeeName
    From
      Employee.csv
      (txt, utf8, no labels, delimiter is ' ', msq)
    ;

Since ADF only supports cosmos db [sql api and mongo api][1],not for table api,it seems that you have to consider using [Migration Tool][2].

You could follow above example command-line:

> dt.exe /s:AzureTable
> /s.ConnectionString:"DefaultEndpointsProtocol=https;AccountName=<Account
> Name>;AccountKey=<Account Key>" /s.Table:metrics /s.InternalFields:All
> /s.Filter:"PartitionKey eq 'Partition1' and RowKey gt '00001'"
> /s.Projection:ObjectCount;ObjectSize  /t:DocumentDBBulk
> /t.ConnectionString:" AccountEndpoint=<CosmosDB
> Endpoint>;AccountKey=<CosmosDB Key>;Database=<CosmosDB Database>;"
> /t.Collection:metrics /t.CollectionThroughput:2500

Then turn it into a bat file and set it to Windows Timing Task.


  [1]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/data-factory/connector-azure-cosmos-db
  [2]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/cosmos-db/import-data#AzureTableSource

answers.body_markdown:
It's not possible to change the gutter width at the moment. It adjusts itself automatically when needed (e.g. there is a gutter icon for override method and a breakpoint on the same line).
Looking at your screenshot, the width is actually standard. It needs some extra space to allow you setting breakpoints without accidentally clicking the line number.
You could submit a feature request/usability problem to https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/issues/IDEA, but to me, it seems fine.

But since you say it was different the other day and then something happened and it became wider, you could try starting PyCharm with default settings by renaming/removing configuration folder. Here is the [article](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/pycharm/directories-used-by-the-ide-to-store-settings-caches-plugins-and-logs.html) on how to find it.

items.body_markdown:
I'm now trying to implement keyset pagination by using SQL tuple comparison. However this will filter out all the null values. So I would like to know if there is a (nice) way to handle such case.

The idea is to use tuple to filter and sort a list based on a primary column and a secondary column (normally it's `id`), following is the sql script for doing this (I take a tinyint column `priority` as primary column)

    SELECT * 
    FROM messages 
    WHERE (priority, id) > (2, 1000) 
    ORDER BY priority asc, id asc

However the `priority` column is nullable (and I would like to keep it this way), so the tuple comparison will filter out all the rows which `priority` is `null`.

I have searched on the internet but there doesn't seem to have any solutions for this problem.

An alternative solution is to use a equivalent sql script instead of tuple comparison, as described in [this answer](https://stackoverflow.com/a/43457966/1720156), the above sql script could be rewritten as 

    SELECT * 
    FROM messages 
    WHERE priority >= 2 
    AND (priority = 2 AND id > 1000 OR priority > 2) 
    ORDER BY priority asc, id asc

The complexity for the script increase exponentially as new condition being included. I don't think my head is clear enough to include null check in this script and I'm all ears if anyone have a proper solution for this.

So all I want to know is that how/if tuple comparison for sql can include null values, and what are the alternatives if it doesn't.
items.title: How to handle null value for tuple comparison in SQL

answers.body_markdown:
names(observations)<-files

That should do the trick.

Or you might want to use only the filenames without the full path:

    names(observations)<-list.files(input_path, pattern="[.]shp$")

This will give you a named vector. If you want to make this into a data.frame with two columns, you can use something like this:

    observations<-data.frame(observations,filename=list.files(input_path, pattern="[.]shp$"),stringsAsFactors=FALSE)

Finally, if for some reason you insist on doing this internally to the loop, you can do this:

    for (i in 1:length(allShapes)){
      observations[i] <- extract(RGB_band1_NOAA, allShapes[[i]], fun=mean, na.rm=TRUE)
      names(observations)[i]<-files[i]
    }

Pragmatical question: **How to include or compute in such correlation test the one-side / one-tail prior ? In order to compute the one-side p-values and correlation coefficients?**

    import scipy.stats, scipy
    A = [-0.10161,0.01737,-0.09379,-0.02382,-0.10354,0.02755,-0.00123,-0.33353,-0.17713,-0.28426,0.01712,-0.07801,-0.6552,0.03631,0.05597,-0.13815,-0.64482,0.07201,-0.45228,0.03905,-0.09762,-0.03492,-0.96015,-0.24642,-0.02859,-0.38284,-0.50422,-0.34073,-0.20625,-0.10509,0.03365,-0.22595,-0.07319,-0.26203,-0.12849,-0.27188]
    B=[0.666666667,0.692307692,0.641025641,0.96875,0.717948718,0.5,0.829787234,0.432432432,0.7,0.319148936,0.673469388,0.815789474,0.102564103,0.666666667,0.358974359,0.6,0.102564103,0.769230769,0.342105263,0.675675676,0.736842105,0.810810811,0.102564103,0.675675676,0.72972973,0.282051282,0.5,0.675675676,0.530612245,0.693877551,0.512820513,0.538461538,0.558823529,0.5,0.846153846,0.35483871]
    print ("Pearson", scipy.stats.pearsonr(A, B))

> - cov(X, Y) = (sum (x - mean(X)) * (y - mean(Y)) ) * 1/(n-1)
- Pearson's correlation coefficient = covariance(X, Y) / (stdv(X) * stdv(Y))

answers.body_markdown:
Your current attempt is pivoting the results; but you can avoid that, and just determine your custom title using String function [`Concat()`][1], and group by on that: 

```sql
SELECT
   CONCAT(tr, 'x') AS level,
   COUNT(*) AS total
FROM
 (select user_id,
         count(subsorder_id) as tr
  from subs_order
  where subsorder_status = 'paid'
  group by user_id) tab
GROUP BY level
```


  [1]: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/string-functions.html#function_concat

answers.body_markdown:
Assuming you have 2 columns before `V` columns we can use `max.col` like


    paste0("Group", max.col(replace(df, is.na(df), 0) == 1) - 2)
    #[1] "Group1" "Group3" "Group2" "Group3" "Group1"


If there are variables in middle columns somwhere, we can subset those and use `max.col`

    sub_df <- df[grep("^V", names(df))]
    paste0("Group", max.col(replace(sub_df, is.na(sub_df), 0) == 1))

items.body_markdown:
We have an app registered on the Azure Portal and we would like to use `MSAL.js` on the front-end and `hapi-auth-jwt2` with `jwks-rsa` on the back-end to authenticate users. The back-end is NOT hosted on Azure but our own MySQL server.

According to this example [active-directory-b2c-javascript-msal-singlepageapp][1] we can use `MSAL.js` to login and either silently or with a pop up acquire ID and Access Tokens. We then attach the **access token** to the http header like this `Vue.prototype.$http.defaults.headers.common['Authorization'] = 'Bearer ' + token` and send a request with `axios` to our back-end `/login` route. When we hit the route from our client, `jwt` auth strategy kicks in and tries to decode the token using the keys retrieved with `jwks-rsa` from the public [https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/discovery/keys][2].

The problem is that the response from `/login` comes with a `401 (Unauthorized)` and `res.headers.www-authenticate: "Bearer error=\"Invalid token\""`. 

When we copy/paste the access token into jwt.io we noticed that our decoded header object consists of `typ`, `nonce`, `alg`, `x5t`, `kid` and the signature comes back as invalid. Also, our App registration had Microsoft Graph with `User.Read` selected under required permissions currently but we removed that.

To test whether the problem is in our JWT strategy, we passed the ID token to Bearer instead of the access token. JWT decoded the token but the response came back with `res.headers.www-authenticate: "Bearer error=\"Invalid credentials\""`

The questions we have are:
 
 1. Is it possible to validate an access token without making a call to Graph API and how do we do that?
 2. If the above is not possible can we authenticate a user using the ID token and how would that work? 
 3. If we can validate access token without a call to Graph API what should be the settings in [https://portal.azure.com/][3]?


  [1]: https://github.com/Azure-Samples/active-directory-b2c-javascript-msal-singlepageapp
  [2]: https://login.microsoftonline.com/common/discovery/keys
  [3]: https://portal.azure.com/
items.title: How to use AzureAD for authentication in Vue / Hapi JS App

answers.body_markdown:
You are doing asynchronus stuff inside your for-loop (your query). The output of "END" is outside of the loop. You are starting 4 Promises, but you are nowhere waiting for them to resolve. So the end is printed first because the for-loop is finished as soon as the Promises are created (not really finished, but javascript contnious with the next command).

You could await the Promise inside your for loop to resolve this.
Instead of 
```javascript
Promise.all([ new_record]).then(function(result)
```
you can use
```javascript
const result = await new_record;
```
Therefore you have to mark the whole function as _async_

I wrap Office-wide functionalities into a first set of interfaces, which are then inherited by a second set of functionalities, which are application-dependent.

Here is a simplified version:

    Region "Office Wrappers"
    
        Interface IApplication(Of T As IFile(Of IVariable))    
            Property Files As IList(Of T)    
        End Interface
    
        Interface IFile(Of T As IVariable)    
            Property Variables As IList(Of T)    
        End Interface
    
        Interface IVariable    
        End Interface    
    
    #End Region    
    
    #Region "Word Wrappers"
    
        Interface IWordApp 'ERROR BC32044
            Inherits IApplication(Of IWordDocument(Of IVariable, IWordParagraph))    
        End Interface
    
        Interface IWordDocument(Of TVar As IVariable, TPara As IWordParagraph)
            Inherits IFile(Of TVar)    
            Property Paragraphs As TPara    
        End Interface
    
        Interface IWordVariable
            Inherits IVariable    
        End Interface
    
        Interface IWordParagraph    
        End Interface
    
    #End Region

The above sample returns an error (see `'ERROR BC32044` comment in the sample):

> Type argument 'IWordDocument(Of IWordVariable, IWordParagraph)' does not inherit from or implement the constraint type 'IFile(Of IVariable)'.

In order to fix this, I need to replace `IWordVariable` by `IVariable` in two instances:

    Interface IWordApp
        Inherits IApplication(Of IWordDocument(Of IVariable, IWordParagraph)) '<- Replacement 1 of 2 here
    End Interface

    Interface IWordDocument(Of TVar As IVariable, TPara As IWordParagraph) '<- Replacement 2 of 2 here
        Inherits IFile(Of TVar)
        Property Paragraphs As TPara
    End Interface

Since `IWordVariable` inherits from `IVariable`, I though `AnyGeneric(Of T as IVariable)` should accept `AnyGeneric(Of IWordVariable)`.

Why does the original code not compile, and how can I fix this?


----------

### Additional information & question ###
I use generics first because each application (Word, Excel, etc) relies on a set of base interfaces (as explained above), but also because I then "extend" each wrapper to expose some custom functionalities. For example:

    Interface IExtendedWordDocument
        Inherits IWordDocument(Of IWordVariable, IExtendedWordParagraph)
    End Interface

    Interface IExtendedWordParagraph
        Inherits IWordParagraph
        Sub SomeCustomActionHere()
    End Interface

Having this system of inheritance allows me to unit test my extended wrappers, whilst I am not too worried about the stability of the Office and Word wrappers, as they basically are a mirror of `Microsoft.Office.Interop`.

Once developing my models, I was hoping to be able to refer to `MyApp As IApplication` or `As IWordApp`, where they would implicitly mean `As IApplication(Of IFile(Of IVariable))` or `As IWordApp(Of IWordDocument(Of IWordVariable, IWordParagraph))`. How could I achieve this?

But for casting to work properly (when passing an `IWordApp` where an `IApplication` is expected), I need to have `IWordApp(Of IWordDocument(Of IWordVariable, IWordParagraph))` to inherit `IApplication` instead of `IApplication(Of IFile(Of IVariable))`, which results in `Me.Variables` to expose `IVariable`, not `IWordVariable`.

When in reality the cascade of generics looks more like this: `IWordApp(Of IDocument(Of IVariables(Of IVariable)), IDocuments(Of IDocument(Of IVariables(Of IVariable))))`, you then understand why I am trying to cut the code required within the models.

answers.body_markdown:
Console.Read();

Only pulls one character at a time from the input stream, but it also doesn't return until the enter key is pressed.  So if you type '1' followed by the enter key, your buffer actually is '1\r\n'.  Because you only have one Console.Read only the '1' is pulled off the buffer; therefore when the first `Console.ReadLine()` is hit the '\r\n' is the pulled off the stream and continues on to your next `Console.ReadLine()`

Call `Console.Read()` twice in a row to to remove the enter key off your stream (once for the '\r' and again for the '\n').

still better use `console.Readline()`

this is a better method since  you don't have to worry about processing individual characters on the stream.

You could create a user-defined function, which should look if the room is reserved or not. This function could take as an input the room id and could return 0, when the room is not booked and 1 when is booked. If we call this function `CheckRoomAvailability`, drop the already defined column and declare it as a computed column:

    ALTER TABLE Rooms
    ADD IsReserved AS dbo.CheckRoomAvailability(Id) 

each time you read from this table, you should see also if it is available or not.

The user defined function I mentioned before, it could be created as below:

    CREATE FUNCTION dbo.CheckRoomAvailability(@RoomId INT)
    RETURNS BIT
    AS 
    BEGIN
        BIT @IsAvailable = 0;

        DATETIME @Now = GETDATE(); // Probably here you need GETUTCDATE(), don't know, if you have chosen or not UTC...

        IF EXISTS(SELECT * 
                  FROM 
                      Reservations 
                  WHERE 
                      RoomId = @RoomId 
                  AND @Now BETWEEN ReservedFrom AND ReservedTo
        )
        BEGIN
            SET @IsAvailable = 1;
        END
    
        RETURN @IsAvailable;
    END

Your code has a few issues:

1. The error message is correct. You are giving it an array, not a string. I think you mean to use the `manager` attribute there (`$data[$i]["manager"][0]`, not `$data[$i]`). In the search results, attributes are all presented as arrays, even if they are single-valued attributes (like `manager`).

2. You are missing the closing parenthesis in the LDAP query. It should look like this:

3. If you are indeed using Active Directory, the attribute is called `distinguishedName`, not `DN` (I believe some OpenLDAP implementations use `DN`, which is why that shows up in documentation).

So your code should look like this:

```php
$result = ldap_search($connect,$ldaptree, "(distinguishedName=" . $data[$i]["manager"][0] . ")") or die ("Error in search query: ".ldap_error($connect));
```
answers.title: Active Directory search using DN (distinguished name)

answers.body_markdown:
You should be able to retrieve the Manager by calling `ldap_search` directly with the DN of the manager as BaseDN and a filter of `(objectclass=*)`

```
$result = ldap_search($connect, $data[$i]['manager'][0], '(objectclass=*)');
```

I updated the answer with the feedback from the OP.

answers.body_markdown:
the "?" character in query is used for parameter substitution. Sqlite will escape the parameter you passed and replace "?" with the send text. So in effect you query after parameter substitution will be ```SELECT 'GNCR' FROM my_table``` where GNCR will be treated as text so you will get the text for each row returned by you query instead of the value of that column.

Basically you should use the query parameter where you want to substitute the parameter with escaped string like in where clause. You can't use it for column name.

answers.body_markdown:
## First solution
Try this code:
    
    import numpy as np
    
    data = []
    with open('data.txt') as my_file:      
        for line in my_file:  
            data.append([list(map(float ,x.split(','))) for x in line.split(' ')])
    arr_data = np.array(data)

and `arr_data` will contain your numpy array:

    array([[[219062.60893, 395935.54879],
            [219332.52719, 395961.82402],
            [219301.47465, 395688.32278],
            [219036.33371, 395677.57382]],
    
           [[218761.63814, 395494.84155],
            [219164.12686, 395438.70811],
            [219086.49551, 395244.03255],
            [218758.05515, 395308.5263 ]]])

Brief explanation:

 1. Read your file line by line
 2. Format and store one line data in a list
 3. Convert list to numpy array

----
## Second solution
Another solution, without external for-loops, which produces the same results:

    arr_data = [[list(map(float, a.split(','))) for a in s] for s in np.loadtxt('myData.csv', dtype=str)]

# Comparison of Execution Times

I used a file like yours format, with 5000 lines, and the results obtained are the following:

 - First Solution:

    `# 41.4 ms ± 4.08 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10 loops each)`

 - Second Solution:

    `# 84.6 ms ± 6.06 ms per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 7 runs, 10 loops each)`

The first solution I proposed to you seems to be about twice as fast.

----
## Extra
If instead you have a *standard csv format*, and you want to upload them directly to a numpy array, you can do so:

    from numpy import genfromtxt
    arr_data = genfromtxt('file_data.csv',delimiter=',')
   
and `my_data` will contain your numpy array.

answers.body_markdown:
I haven't tested it yet but maybe it could work as an alternative.

Sometimes, when we need to get the value in the state, we usually do the spread operator within the state but it doesn't guarantees that the value is the correct one. For those cases, we better call `setState` with a callback which takes the previous value from state. So, you can use something like this:

```Javascript
setValues(prev => ({...prev, val1:'11111'}));
```
answers.title: React useState when updating state twice, first update gets deleted
React useState when updating state twice, first update gets deleted

answers.body_markdown:
The behaviour of the code becomes clear once we note that `values` variable in func2 is clousre on `values` at outer scope, which is really a copy of state taken at the time `useState` was called.

So what your spreading in `func2` is is stale copy of your state.

One way of correcting this would be to use [functional update][1] 


	setValues((values) => ({...values, val2: result}));

This will make sure that you are using updated value of the state.


  [1]: https://reactjs.org/docs/hooks-reference.html#functional-updates

answers.body_markdown:
Cascading delete is enabled by default when you create a foreign key relationship on a required (or non-nullable) property, see [EF required relationship][1]

The problem here is that you have 2 cascading delete paths from `InvoicePaymentParticipant` to your `ApplicationUser` table:

    Path1: InvoicePaymentParticipant -> InvoicePayment -> Invoice -> ApplicationUser

    Path2: InvoicePaymentParticipant -> ApplicationUser

This means, when you delete a user, the following records should be deleted:

**Deletions under path 1:**

1. when *user* is deleted, delete his *invoices*
2. when *invoice* is deleted, delete corresponding *invoice payments*
3. when *invoice payment* is deleted, delete corresponding *invoice payment participants*

**Deletions under path 2:**

1. when *user* is deleted, delete his *invoice payment participants*

This is not allowed in Sql Server. See [this page][2] for more info.

To solve the problem, you can reconsider your table structure and remove one of the foreign key paths from `InvoicePaymentParticipant` to `ApplicationUser`... 

The other approach would be to change the cascading delete behavior of the foreign key, you can remove the `[Required]` attribute on one of the `ManagerId` properties and since `string` is a `nullable` type, EF would set the [key to null][3] on delete. 

You can also change EF default behavior and [turn off cascading delete][4]



  [1]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/ef/core/saving/cascade-delete#required-relationships
  [2]: https://www.mssqltips.com/sqlservertip/2733/solving-the-sql-server-multiple-cascade-path-issue-with-a-trigger/
  [3]: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/ef/core/saving/cascade-delete#optional-relationships
  [4]: https://www.entityframeworktutorial.net/code-first/cascade-delete-in-code-first.aspx
